    Head L (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [20th March, 1996],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head L of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Dr Ong Chit Chung].

    Question again proposed.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang)( In Mandarin): Sir, since last year, the Ministry of Education has been giving "high value added" awards to schools that perform better than expectation in the "O" level examination. This award has been categorized into Express and Normal streams. To the neighbourhood schools, this is an incentive, and good for morale boosting. But the challenge faced by the schools today is how to teach the Normal (Technical) class. The Ministry of Education should pay more attention to these students and to affirm the teachers and schools in their efforts in teaching these Normal (Technical) students. In some schools, for certain reasons, they are not able to achieve any breakthrough in their academic results. They therefore are not encouraged by the rewards based on results. What is the attitude of the Ministry of Education on these schools? Are these schools left to fend for themselves and to solve their own problems? Does the Ministry of Education assist in their problems? What assistance does the Ministry currently provide to these schools?

     The Minister for Education (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Sir, I propose to answer a few of the points raised under this cut. My colleagues, Dr Aline Wong and Mr Sidek Saniff, will answer the rest.

    Yesterday, Mr Sinnakaruppan was commenting on the staff appraisal system

Column: 1791

in schools. The new appraisal and ranking system was implemented service-wide starting from last year. It is a rigorous system that involves not only the assessment of a teacher's performance but also his or her potential to hold higher appointments in relation to other teachers in the school. My Ministry has considered using a point system for appraisal before. However, such a system may not remove the element of subjectivity since ultimately the supervisors who are the principal, vice-principal and heads of department still have to make their judgment as to whether a particular teacher is good or bad based on his relative strengths and weaknesses in various dimensions. Moreover, there is also an element of subjectivity in deciding the relative weight to be accorded to each of these dimensions.

    I would like to inform the House that my Ministry is fully aware of the problems encountered by schools during the ranking exercise. Many of these are teething problems as teachers were ranked for the first time last year. My Ministry will fine-tune the system in order to iron out these problems.

    Both Mr Sinnakaruppan and Mr Lew Syn Pau asked about the schools' teaching of the thinking programme. My Ministry introduced in 1987, which is about 10 years ago, the Edward de Bono's CORT (Cognitive Research Trust) programme in secondary schools. At present, there are about 103 secondary schools which are implementing the CORT programme. My Ministry is refining and extending this programme to other secondary schools. Our aim is to help our pupils become better and more creative thinkers and learners by teaching them the core thinking skills explicitly and infusing these skills into the learning subjects in the curriculum. The revised programme is presently being piloted at Secondary 1 in five schools, as announced by Dr Aline Wong in November last year. Teachers in these schools are trained and teachers' manuals incorporating lesson plans, visual aids and pupil worksheets have been developed for the programme. The

Column: 1792

thinking programme will be phased into all secondary schools over the next four years. By the year 2000, all secondary schools will be on the programme.

    My Ministry recognises the importance of encouraging critical and creative thinking among our pupils from an early age. When we piloted the CORT programme in 1986, we found that the explicit teaching of thinking in primary schools was not as beneficial as incorporating thinking into the teaching of the subjects. We have therefore consciously included some critical and creative thinking skills into the teaching of language, mathematics and science in the primary school curriculum. For example, in English, pupils are taught to make comparisons and inferences in reading and comprehension and to give creative ideas in writing. In mathematics, the emphasis is on seeing relationships in patterns and on being able to solve mathematical problems. In science, pupils are taught to analyse and to make deductions and come to conclusions based on observations and simple experiments.

    Dr Ong Chit Chung asked yesterday about the progress of the National Institute of Education (NIE). My impression is that NIE is doing well. However, it is for Members and the public to judge. The BA and BSc with Diploma in Education programmes were successfully implemented. In 1995, the first batch of 83 and 30 students graduated in BA and BSc with Diploma in Education respectively.

    Currently, all students pursuing teaching training courses at the NIE are bonded to serve the Ministry of Education for three or five years upon completion of their course. It is difficult for me to accept at this stage Dr Ong's proposal that NIE admit fee-paying students who are not bonded to teach in our schools. One reason is that in the coming years, the requirement for NIE to train more teachers for our schools will be increased significantly. NIE does not have spare capacity to train those who may not take up teaching as a career upon the completion of their NIE studies. However, for those who are generally interested in the field of education and do not wish to be bonded

Column: 1793

to teach in a school, NIE does offer higher degree courses, such as the Master of Education and the Master of Arts and Applied Linguistics. These courses are run on a part-time basis and are open to working adults.

    I would like now to turn to the question of tertiary education. Several Members spoke on this yesterday. Mr Umar and Mr Chiam See Tong, who is not here, asked that we increase the university places in Singapore. In considering whether to provide more university places we should bear in mind that we already have two large universities which together will take in about 20% of each cohort after 'A' levels and four big polytechnics which will take in about 40% of a cohort after 'O' levels. Each polytechnic will take in about 4,000 new students a year, almost the same number as the intake into NUS or NTU. In total, we will be providing places for about 60% of each age cohort in our tertiary institutes. This is one of the highest such percentages in the world.

    About 10 years ago, the British converted all their polytechnics into new universities, thereby doubling the number of universities to almost 100 to achieve their target of about 30% in tertiary institutes. Several years ago, Hong Kong followed suit. Had we done something similar, we would already have six large universities for a small country of 3 million people.

    Mr Chiam mentioned the ratio of one university to about half a million population in Australia and New Zealand. But how big are these universities? And are they all of the university standard as we understand it? We are doing the right thing here by keeping our polytechnics as polytechnics. They have a vital role to play in educating and training our middle level manpower to provide the backbone of our economy. Overseas experts who visit or work with our polytechnics are impressed with their facilities and programmes which are better than those of some universities overseas. A former British Education Secretary told me he thought we did right in keeping the polytechnics as they were.

    Recent British press reports indicate that many UK employers are reluctant to accept

Column: 1794

the degrees of their new universities at face value. They insist on at least a second class Honours degree from a traditional university. Having over-expanded their capacities and with grants tied to student numbers, some universities are even taking students without 'A' levels and putting them on foundation courses. Singaporeans need to be aware of what is happening in the field of higher education overseas. There is a very wide variation in the quality and value of foreign degree programmes. This is compounded by the problem of declining educational achievement and standards as some countries have embarked on so-called mass production of graduates on weaker educational foundations. Over-expansion of capacity and funding difficulties have led to aggressive marketing overseas.

    In Singapore, we have rapidly expanded undergraduate places at NUS and NTU over the past decade whilst maintaining educational standards. They are taking in as many students as are able to make the grade. For some courses, such as science, there are in fact more places than qualified applicants. The two universities are also taking in more polytechnic graduates. An increasing number of able students are choosing to go into university through the polytechnic route although the vast majority still go through the junior colleges, the preferred route. The polytechnics are also serving as stepping stones to many universities in UK and Australia which provide advanced standing to polytechnic graduates in related courses. However, for the vast majority of polytechnic graduates, the three-year diploma course already provides a good foundation to start their careers and to upgrade their knowledge and skills on the job. After some working experience, they could pursue higher qualifications, if they wish, through part-time or full-time courses at our universities, polytechnics or overseas.

    The Government has invested heavily in our tertiary institutes to cater to the aspirations of Singaporeans to pursue further studies. Our aim is to maximise the potential of every Singaporean according to his ability and aptitude. Through the provision of training places in the relevant

Column: 1795

areas and at various levels, we also try to match our output of educated and trained manpower with the needs of our economy.

    Mindful of Singaporeans' aspirations, the Government has in recent years also allowed various professional organisations, such as the Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) and the Institute of Banking and Finance to collaborate with foreign universities which offer degree programmes here on part-time or full-time basis. Total enrolment is about 10,000 students in both undergraduate and postgraduate programmes, including about 3,000 in the Open University Degree Programmes at SIM.

    My Ministry has been reviewing the situation and may selectively allow a few more such degree programmes to be offered here. The type and form of such programmes are still under consideration. However, we should be mindful that private organisations are profit-oriented and may not have the standard of quality control that we desire.

    Our booming economy is faced with a manpower supply constraint not only in numbers but also in terms of talent distribution. Not everyone can make it through a rigorous university programme. However, with affluence, many Singaporeans will aspire to pursue some kind of degree programme here or overseas. They should ask themselves whether the investment is worthwhile and the programme is of acceptable quality. Ultimately, the market will find its own level as employers become more discerning but the process is wasteful and will lead to unfulfilled expectations. To make up for our shortfall in manpower, we must continue to attract talent from abroad.

    Here, I am pleased to note that Mr Chiam supports the admission of more foreign students into our universities. This is one way to attract talent and to provide a more stimulating environment in our universities. At present, foreign students make up less than 10% of the enrolment in NUS and NTU.

Column: 1796



    The admission of foreign students into our universities will not be at the expense of our own students. I wish to assure all Singaporeans that NUS and NTU will take in as many local students as are able to benefit from the programmes and pass. Foreign students have to pay higher fees. They also have to be academically better than local students to qualify. The number of places for foreign students is over and above those provided for local students. If there are more qualified applicants, both local and foreign, we are prepared to provide more university places to accommodate them.

    In our manpower planning, it is important that we try and match the output of graduates in different disciplines with future demand. We also need to spread our talent to the different specialisations. Students and parents tend to over-react to short-term market perceptions, for example, more students are gravitating to business courses at the expense of engineering and science. We need to guide them in their choices. Otherwise, competition for places is based on `A' level results, except for some courses like medicine, law and architecture where they require interviews and selection tests. Those who do better in the `A' level results and at the interviews are more likely to get places of their choice.

    I think this answer also covers the points raised by Mr Umar essentially. The main challenges that the polytechnics will be facing in future will be, firstly, to make sure that the courses remain relevant to the needs of industry. This is very important. The second major challenge for them is to ensure that our students, besides possessing basic technical knowledge and skills, are also flexible and adaptable. They must be able to continually learn and upgrade themselves so as to keep up with new demands and rapid technological changes at the workplace.

    Mr Kenneth Chen was concerned that, with the improvement in the school results year by year, the better students will displace the weaker ones going to the polytechnics. I share his concern to some extent about this gradual erosion of the educational qualifications. This is partly

Column: 1797

because our students are performing much better than students in the United Kingdom. And as Members know, we are having these GCE `O' and `A' level examinations together with the Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate. The problem is that the educational standards have been declining in the western countries. Our students here have been very hardworking and we have stuck to the traditional methods where we assess the students regularly and set high standards for them. Our students have been improving year by year. But some of the improvements in results may have been because, as I said, the standards may have been falling over the years.

    The question is whether our distribution of places in universities, in polytechnics, in the ITE, is appropriate for our needs. And if we maintain standards and make sure that we take in students who are really able to go through the course, then it should not matter despite this grade inflation. In practice, for example, the students who are going to polytechnics, the better `O' level students, are mainly going into commerce related subjects and other students who want to go into engineering and so forth are still able to find places. So I would like to assure him that all students who complete their 10 years of general education will have the opportunity to progress further and complete their education locally at the ITE, the polytechnics or the universities.

    In terms of numbers, the polytechnics will be taking in, in total, about 16,000 students. Some of them will upgrade to degrees either immediately after completion of the polytechnic education or later on. And very often, it is in related areas. For example, engineering students with a diploma in engineering tend to go into a degree in engineering. So there is, in fact, no loss of relevance in that sense. We are comfortable that the output will be adequate to meet our needs.

    Mr Umar has stressed the importance of upgrading the quality of our universities through research and so on, and I agree fully with him. I think the two universities that we have are doing well. They are improving in their standards year by year

Column: 1798

and also in terms of the work that they are doing in R&D. We should do our best to build up the two universities into world-class universities, at least in some areas of specialisation.

    I would give Members some ideas about the amount of money we are spending on research. In the last two years, about $119 million had been committed to fund approved research projects. The main source of funding is the academic research fund, while the National Science and Technology Board, other statutory boards and industries also make contributions. In addition, an amount of $32 million was given out as research scholarships and studentships to post-graduate research students in the universities. This is to attract more people to undertake post-graduate research work and to build up Singapore's R&D manpower.

    The progress of the two universities in research has been good and the research output has been laudable as evident in the increasing list of research publications. In 1994, it amounted to about 3,700, an increase of 16% over that in 1993, and many of these are published in international revered journals. So far, 40 patents have been filed or granted. In addition, since 1994, NUS and NTU have formed four and two spin-off companies from their respective research activities. All these developments have placed our universities in good stead, relative to reputable foreign universities. NUS and NTU will continue to strive for excellence in their R&D activities. They will form a basis for wealth creation in the economy through the continual transfer of technology to industry.

    Next, I like to move on to this question of the neighbourhood schools which was raised by Dr Ong Chit Chung. I agree with him that we should pay utmost attention to these schools because these are the schools where most of our students are and, in fact, we are doing that. So, in that sense, there is really no need for a special unit in the Ministry to do this because the whole Ministry is actually doing it.

    Neighbourhood schools are equally well provided for in terms of staff and facilities.

Column: 1799

Many neighbourhood schools have been given new and modern buildings with excellent facilities, and other neighbourhood schools have been physically upgraded. For example, under the rebuilding and extension programme still in progress for 37 secondary schools costing $566 million, 31 are neighbourhood schools. So it is fair. In fact, the majority are neighbourhood schools. We also make sure that we have a good distribution of teachers and principals to the different schools and there is no discrimination against neighbourhood schools. As I have explained before, the teachers who are good in teaching the average children may not be the same teachers who are good in teaching very bright children. So we have to try and make sure that we match the requirements.

    The focus on the neighbourhood schools is to try and upgrade them and in the process uplift the education standards in all our schools. To recognise the good work put in by the neighbourhood schools, the Ministry of Eduction has given special awards to top value-added schools in the 1994 GCE `O' level examination. Of the 31 schools which received the awards, 84% were neighbourhood schools. The good leadership in these schools as well as the hard work and dedication of the teachers are recognised and publicised through these awards which will be given annually.

    Next, I turn to the question raised by Dr Arthur Beng. He was speaking on behalf of parents who have to work overseas. As Members know, we have a school in Hong Kong at primary level and we are able to do that because there is a critical mass of Singaporean students there. I think the school has been doing very well and we are proud of it. The Ministry will consider having similar schools elsewhere provided there is enough number of students to form a school. Where there are not enough students, a more practical approach for parents is to put their children in International Schools. Where they want to supplement the curriculum of the International Schools with learning of mother tongue, this is an area where we

Column: 1800

can assist. As Members may have read in the newspapers, we are posting some officers to Bangkok to study how we can start such a programme in Bangkok to cater to the learning of mother tongue. Depending on the experience of that scheme, we may extend it to other areas.

    Dr Arthur Beng also asked whether tax deductions could be given for children who accompany their parents on overseas postings. The Finance Minister is not here. This matter really has to be referred to him. I am not sure whether it is necessary and how it will work out. Most employers do provide child educational allowances as part of the remuneration package for employees posted overseas.

    The Ministry will continue to be flexible in the application of our bilingual policy to ensure that pupils returning from abroad are not disadvantaged. Pupils who have been overseas for some time and have not been able to maintain their exposure to the mother tongue can apply to offer another foreign language instead or apply for exemption from offering a second language. The Ministry will consider each case individually.

    Dr Arthur Beng yesterday raised a case of one family with two children. One is 10 years old, coming back at Primary Three. So he is exempted from doing the mother tongue for the PSLE, because it is not reasonable to expect the child to complete the primary school syllabus in just three years. However, the younger child who joins at Primary One is required to do Chinese and to take the PSLE in Chinese. I think this is reasonable because most of our Singaporean children, in fact, are doing the same thing, even though this particular child has missed out on the kindergarten part of it. If need be, additional help can be given to the child to help overcome the initial bridging problems.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan spoke on the importance of regionalising our educational services. As noted by her, the NUS Business Administration Faculty and NTU's Nanyang Business School already run MBA and executive management programmes that take in foreign students.

Column: 1801

They are essentially self-financing and are either taught by NUS or NTU academic staff only or co-taught with foreign academics.

    The MBA Programme in Chinese at NUS, for example, has over 70% of its full-time students from overseas. Other shorter executive programmes conducted by both universities have attracted participants from some 73 countries in the region and outside.

    Among other areas, the two universities are developing an expertise on economic and business practices in the region. This expertise will be valuable to students in Asia as well as westerners who are interested in participating in the growth of the region.

    Dr Lee has suggested that business and management programmes be established abroad as well. NUS and NTU have already begun to do this. Short executive development programmes have been initiated, usually in collaboration with local institutions, in various countries around the region, including Malaysia, Thailand and the PRC. In April 1996, NUS will bring the prestigious joint Stanford University-NUS executive programmes to Hong Kong. In June 1995, NTU signed a Memorandum of Understanding to develop an undergraduate accountancy degree programme at Fudan University in the PRC.

    Besides business courses, we are also attracting students here to study English, computing and other subjects. Whilst we should do more to export our educational service, it is manpower-intensive and requires high level manpower. As it is, we are short of teachers for our schools and many of our university staff are recruited from overseas. To the extent that we can build up our capacity and have a room to spare, we can certainly do more to regionalise our educational services.

    The last item I want to touch on is the value-added awards raised by Mr Low Thia Khiang. Since last year, the Ministry has been giving monetary awards to schools which have helped their pupils

Column: 1802

perform better than expected based on their PSLE entry scores. These are so-called high value-added schools. The top 10 schools in the Special, Express and Normal courses receive $20,000 each, while the next 10 in both categories receive $10,000 each. The Ministry likewise intends to reward the high value-added schools for the Normal (Technical) Stream. As it is desirable to use the national examination results for the purpose, my Ministry will rank the schools only after the first batch of Normal (Technical) pupils have taken their GCE `N' level examinations in 1997.

    Schools are conscious of the fact that they should meet expectations in the academic output in relation to the quality of pupil intake and are channelling their efforts in this direction. Pupils' academic performance fluctuates from year to year in some schools. Patterns of performance are monitored closely by the schools and by my Ministry. More focus is placed on schools which have difficulty in making improvements. They will receive more guidance and assistance from school inspectors and subject specialists for the particular departments or for the school as a whole. I hope this will address his concern. We will certainly do our best to help those schools which have problems.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Bedok GRC): Sir, on a point of clarification. When I brought up the case of a Primary 1 boy who came back from overseas, the understanding that I got from the Ministry of Education was that this child has got many years to catch up with. But I am sure the Minister will agree that having missed K1 and K2 in Singapore and going straight into Mandarin in the bilingual system at Primary 1, it would be a problem for the child. The parents are trying hard and the child is trying hard. I also received a reply from the Ministry of Education that the principal and teachers are helping the child. But what I am asking the Minister is, if the child is still not able to make it by the time he reaches Primary 3 or Primary 4, will he be given some consideration. There should be some flexibility in the system. The parents are definitely trying hard and they want their child to fit into the bilingual system.

Column: 1803



     Mr Lee Yock Suan: While I sympathise with this case, I am not sure how Members feel about it. This child is starting right from the beginning in our formal school system at Primary 1 and he has the full six years to master the language. Special help can be given but I am not sure whether there is a case for special consideration. In this particular case, I understand that one of the parents is an Eurasian, so maybe there is some difficulty in the family background. And for children of mixed marriages, our rules do provide some flexibility. But in this particular case, having missed out K1 and K2, I think it is not really a very big hurdle because K1 and K2 are basically more like play-schools.

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Dr Aline K. Wong): Sir, a number of Members have asked whether Edusave can be extended to junior colleges, centralised institutes (CIs), Institute of Technical Education (ITE) as well as the special schools. The Edusave Scheme currently provides for contributions to Edusave accounts of pupils between ages 6 and 16 years as well as grants to all primary and secondary schools (except independent schools), scholarships for students in all secondary schools and Edusave Merit Bursaries for primary and secondary schools. So the Edusave Scheme has a number of attached programmes.

    The Edusave Merit Bursary Scheme was implemented last year to motivate pupils in primary and secondary schools who come from low and lower-middle income families to perform well academically. The value of the yearly awards is $150 for Primary 1-3, $200 for Primary 4-6 and $250 for Secondary 1-5. Last year, a total of about 47,000 primary and secondary pupils received the bursary amounting to about $9.5 million. These pupils are within the top 25% of each level and stream, with family income below $3,000 per month.

    The Ministry of Education has decided to extend the Edusave Merit Bursary Scheme to junior colleges and centralised institutes to give bright students from poorer families an incentive to perform well. The eligibility criteria would be

Column: 1804

similar to that in primary and secondary schools, that is, students within the top 25% of each level in each JC and CI whose family income is less than $3,000 per month.

    The scheme will also be extended to full-time students in the Institute of Technical Education who meet the same criteria. However, trainees in the Apprenticeship and Continuing Education and Training Programmes will not be eligible as most of them are working adults. So the extension of this scheme to ITE students is only for the full-time students.

    The value of the bursary is $300 for the pre-university level and $400 for ITE, which are higher than the rate for secondary schools because of the higher expenses of post-secondary students.

    The Edusave Merit Bursary for pre-university and ITE will be awarded at the end of 1996.

    Edusave grants are currently given to primary and secondary schools to enable them to purchase resources and introduce enrichment programmes to enhance the quality of teaching and learning. Primary and secondary schools currently receive an Edusave grant of $50 and $90 per pupil respectively.

    The Ministry has decided to give an Edusave grant to junior colleges and centralised institutes at the rate of $120 per pupil, and a grant to technical institutes at the rate of $100 per pupil. Independent schools, which at present do not receive the Edusave grant, will also be given the grant at the rate of $90 per pupil, similar to the Government and Government-aided secondary schools. The extension of Edusave grants to JCs, CIs, ITE and independent schools will be implemented in 1997.

    We estimate that a sum of about $1.8 million will be spent on the Edusave Merit Bursary Scheme for junior colleges, centralised institutes and ITE in 1996. The disbursement of Edusave grants to junior colleges, centralised institutes, ITE and independent schools in 1997 will require about $4.8 million which will be provided in next year's budget.

    There are currently 15 Government-supported special education (SPED) schools providing education to some 3,000 disabled children in Singapore. These SPED schools are run by voluntary welfare organisations. And the Ministry supervises and monitors these schools as well as provides capitation grants for 50% of their recurrent expenditures.

    At present, the SPED schools are not included in the Edusave Scheme. The Government has received many appeals from Members of the House as well as the National Council of Social Service.

    I am pleased to announce that the Ministry has decided to extend the Edusave Scheme to children in the special schools starting from 1996. They can use Edusave for programmes which are over and above the basic education and training programmes, such as special outings, survival skills in water, computer-assisted learning and even aesthetic activities for some children.

    Eligible children in the special schools will receive an Edusave contribution of $130 in 1996. In addition, the SPED schools will also receive an Edusave grant at $50 per pupil, similar to the primary schools. The budget required is around $540,000. More details on the scheme will be made known to the SPED schools at a later date.

    Mr Umar asked whether the Edusave Merit Bursary Scheme could also be extended to polytechnic students. I would like to remind Members that the scheme is designed for students between ages 6 and 16, that is, for primary and secondary students. Polytechnic students are generally regarded as studying in tertiary education institutions and when they graduate from these institutions, they can earn better income than those who do not. So for polytechnic students, we have decided not to extend the Edusave Scheme to them. But if they are in any financial difficulty, the polytechnics have established tuition fee loan schemes, bursaries and other financial assistance for them.

    He also asked whether the Edusave Merit Bursary scheme could be extended

Column: 1806

to the top 30% of the student population. The question is where do we stop. I think 25% is already quite a broad band. Since the scheme only came into existence last year, we would like to monitor the effectiveness of the scheme whose purpose is to motivate more pupils from the lower income families to do well in schools. So we would like to see whether this scheme has met its objective before considering whether it should be extended further.

    Dr Ong Chit Chung asked what further things we are doing for students in the special education schools. I have just announced that, with effect from this year, the children who attend SPED schools will be receiving Edusave contributions. And these schools will also receive Edusave grants. I am also pleased to tell him that, by way of helping the schools with their capital expenditures, the Ministry will from this year revise the funding formula from 80/20 to 90/10, that is, the Ministry would bear 90% of the capital expenditure. We should note that the Government has already been providing renovated school buildings to them and we also bear the cyclical repair costs. This new funding formula will further assist them in developing purpose-built schools in future.

    As regards students with some learning difficulties, especially those known to be having dyslexia, Dr Ong also asked what we are doing to help them. The Ministry is working in collaboration with the Dyslexia Association of Singapore to help Primary 1 to Primary 4 pupils with dyslexia to overcome their learning disabilities. We have given the Dyslexia Association a start-up grant of up to $500,000 to set up their second Dyslexia Centre in Ping Yi Primary School. They already have one in Clementi. We have provided a start-up grant for the cost of the renovations and also to help them cover their operating deficit in the initial years. Eventually, they are expected to become self-financing.
1.15 pm

    The dyslexia centre at Ping Yi School actually started operation in January this year, with about 29 Primary One to Primary Four pupils. It is expected that

Column: 1807

when the school is operating in full capacity, it can accommodate 200 pupils. The above-average as well as the average pupils who are identified by school teachers as being moderately to severely dyslexic are referred to the Dyslexia Association's centres where they will receive extra remedial tuition conducted by specialist teachers. These remedial lessons last for about an hour per session and most students attend twice a week. Each remedial group consists of a very small number of students, varying between four and six. Once these students overcome the learning disability, they need not continue with their remedial lessons.

    As I said, the Dyslexia Association of Singapore has another centre in Clementi Community Centre and they are providing remedial tuition for about 32 Primary One to Primary Four pupils. The Association is charging a fee of $1,400 a year per pupil. But for needy students, the Ministry helps them by providing financial assistance.

    Let me come to the subject of information technology (IT). Dr Arthur Beng, Mr Sinnakaruppan and also Dr Ong Chit Chung have spoken on it. There is no question that the revolution in IT will have revolutionary effects on the way we live, study and work, and the way we spend our leisure hours. To face this challenge and in preparation for the 21st century, my Ministry is putting in place a very comprehensive programme to introduce IT in our schools.

    Very broadly speaking, IT is introduced in three ways. First, use of IT as a teaching tool; second, the teaching of IT in schools; third, provision and exposure to IT in schools. We use IT as a teaching tool or what is known as computer-based learning in our schools. All the schools are being provided with 1-2 computer laboratories. The facilities are already in place in all junior colleges and secondary schools. The provisions in the primary schools should be completed by early next year, once the necessary renovations are completed. Some of our primary schools do not have the necessary infrastructure

Column: 1808

like electricity loading, etc, for the additional number of computers. So we have to wait for the renovations to be completed for all the primary schools, so that they could be provided with computers. The target date is early next year.

    Beyond the provision of hardware, the challenge is to ensure that our teachers are adequately trained and that we have enough appropriate courseware to use IT to teach the curriculum subjects.

    In the primary schools, the emphasis is on using the computer as a teaching and learning tool. The idea is to integrate IT into existing curriculum subjects. With the assistance of the National Computer Board, the strategy has been to implement the IT programme on a pilot basis in six schools, while preparing for the roll-out to the remaining 191 primary schools.

    The pilot programme known as Accelerating the Use of IT in Primary Schools (AITP) was launched in mid-1995. The scope of this pilot project involves all streams at the primary level and, wherever possible, all the subjects. So we are piloting the use of computer-based learning for most curriculum subjects. We are sourcing for suitable courseware which is available in the commercial market and which can be integrated into our teaching of the subject matters. Our Curriculum Development Institute is also developing its own courseware. To begin with, we are developing courseware in Mathematics.

    At the secondary school level, the Ministry is piloting a special project which Members may have heard or read about in the papers. This is known as the Students' and Teachers' Workbench (STW). This is a flagship project in the National Computer Board's IT 2000 Vision of turning Singapore into an intelligent island. The pilot project which began in January 1996, as scheduled, is implemented in six secondary schools. And in each of these schools, the STW is used by 3-6 teachers to teach science in Secondary One. A total of 2,000 Secondary One students in all streams in these schools are presently using the STW

Column: 1809

system. The system is being used in the STW classrooms, in the science laboratories as well as the resource rooms.

    The STW is essentially a central collection of educational resources which both the teachers and the students can access very easily, at the touch of a few buttons. It is hooked to Internet and it utilises multi-media resources. We have received some very positive feedback so far. So we may have to look into extending the STW to Secondary Two next year.

    In addition to AITP and STW, the Ministry encourages the development of more multi-media CD-ROM titles for schools to choose from. And we are working very closely with the National Computer Board as well as the private industries in developing the software and to keep them updated about our school requirements.

    As I mentioned, IT is not only used as a teaching tool, it is also being taught as a special area in our schools, beginning with keyboarding. Keyboarding is a very basic skill for using computers effectively and efficiently. And we have been teaching keyboarding to Primary Five pupils in some schools already. From the feedback we have obtained, it is considered to be very useful and essential. So we have plans to teach keyboarding skills for primary students at earlier levels.

    In the secondary schools, IT is taught as a core subject called "Computer Applications" in the Normal (Technical) stream. These students in the Normal (Technical) stream will acquire practical skills in word processing, in desktop publishing, graphics and design. At the junior college level, interested students can offer "Computing" as an elective 'A' level subject. At present, we do not plan to introduce IT as a separate learning subject in secondary schools along the same lines as, say, English and Mathematics. Our approach is to integrate the use of IT in the learning of these subjects. I think in this way, it would be more fun and it would stimulate students' thinking skills, than to teach IT as a separate subject in the secondary schools.

    Finally, on the provision and exposure of IT in schools, we are providing

Column: 1810

computer laboratories as standard resources. At the same time, we are looking into putting computers in some classrooms, science laboratories, resource rooms and other appropriate areas within the school, such as in some open spaces and in staff rooms, so that both students and teachers can have access to the computers after school hours. So through such an IT-enriched environment and curriculum in the schools, we can further develop our students' thinking skills and capacity for harnessing the usefulness of IT in the learning process and to prepare them for the later challenges of working life.

    Dr Arthur Beng and Mr Sinnakaruppan asked for some specific statistics about the extent of how IT is being provided in the schools. As to how many teachers have been trained, so far, about 3,000 primary and 6,000 secondary teachers have attended various computer courses. These courses expose them to computer literacy as well as teach them how to use the computer effectively in teaching curriculum subjects.

    Do we provide the latest Pentium computers? As a guiding principle, the Ministry provides up-to-date models which are capable of remaining current for the next 4-5 years. We all know computers are very expensive and they can become obsolete in 4-5 years' time. Our principle is to provide up-to-date models which are capable of at least being in use for 4-5 years.

    For the AITP project, the schools are provided with multi-media Pentiums or Macintosh Performas. For the STW, schools are given a mix of 486s and Pentiums. But I think we have to evaluate whether the use of these computers is cost effective in teaching students at various levels. Even in a country like Isreal where they have pushed IT in schools on a very big scale, they are not using the latest type of computers or the most powerful type for the lower level school students. I think we have to be a bit cautious in spending money on acquiring hardware.

    As to how many computers are provided to schools for administrative

Column: 1811

use, currently, five computers are provided for every primary and secondary school for administrative use. Another six will be added this year. So there will be a total of 11 computers which will be linked to a school local area network called the LAN System.

    Do we have a target for computer-teacher and computer-student ratios? For the AITP roll-out plan, we are working towards one PC for every five teachers and one PC for every 15 pupils. But I think we have to feel our way. From our pilot study, we have to evaluate the effectiveness of the ratios. We cannot stick to it as a hard and fast rule.

    As to what steps we are taking to increase home ownership of computers, it would be ideal if every school student in Singapore can own a home computer. In fact, Singapore already has one of the highest ownership of computers in the world, granted that some homes have more than one computer and some homes do not have any. Yes, we could look into various ways to help students have access to computers at home. But first, we can provide more access to computers at the school, if students cannot afford to have one at home. By putting more computers in resource rooms, libraries, in open areas in schools and so on, we can help students to have access to the computers, even if they do not own one at home.

    I am sorry, when I looked at Dr Soin, I realised that I had missed her question regarding special schools. Let me just go back very briefly. She asked whether the Ministry can consider funding 100% of the education component of the special school's recurrent expenditure. She knows that we are funding 50% of the recurrent expenditure of special schools. Within this funding principle, there is some variation with regard to the kind of programmes that the students attend. Let me point out that the so-called two tier per capita cap is an internal arrangement within the National Council of Social Service only. It is true that during the last two years, the Ministry had been flexible in giving more

Column: 1812

per capita grant to three schools catering to the multiple handicapped. However, two years of flexibility does not establish a rule. I think she would agree with me that it is very difficult to distinguish between the education and welfare components in providing for students in SPED schools. Even for the education component, it is very difficult to distinguish between the basic education part, ie, training, like other students, for numeracy and literacy, and the rehabilitative part where the students receive speech, physio or occupational therapy. So for the moment, let us continue to work within this formula. It has served us well and we will have to watch for the cost effectiveness of the programmes at the SPED schools.

    I think she should be happy with so many benefits that we have announced today for the SPED schools.

    Let me come to the questions on mother tongue. Mr Peh Chin Hua has spoken on the need for us to put greater emphasis on teaching the mother tongue not only orally but also in reading and writing. He also mentioned that we should allow the students greater exposure to the mother tongue through teaching some more subjects in the mother tongue.

    Let me assure him that the teaching of the Chinese language provides for a balance in the language skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing in order to help the pupils attain proficiency. We put adequate emphasis on reading and writing, both at the primary and secondary levels. Both the skills are taught as well as examined.

    In the national examinations, the oral skills take up 20% of the assessment, while reading and writing take up 80%. As for exposure to more subjects in the mother tongue, and he referred to the Chinese language, let me inform him that at both the secondary and pre-university levels, there is provision for the learning of Chinese literature. In addition, at the pre-university level, pupils may offer History in Chinese. Starting last year, a new subject called General Studies in

Column: 1813

Chinese offered at the `AO' level was made available. For other subjects like physical education, moral education, music and art, teachers may use Chinese in classes where all the pupils take Chinese as the mother tongue. The SAP schools are given the flexibility to teach moral education and some other subjects in Mandarin, if not all the time, at least whenever they feel the need to do so. They are given this flexibility.

    Dr Ow asked about the progress in implementation of the recommendations of the Report of the Chinese Language Review Committee chaired by Mr Ong Teng Cheong. Specifically, he asked four points. One, the revision of the Chinese Language syllabus for primary and secondary school students. I would like to inform him that we began to implement the revised syllabuses from 1995 by levels. This year, pupils in Primary 1 to 3, and Secondary 1 to 2, both Special and Express streams, as well as Secondary 1 to 3, Normal (Academic) and Normal (Technical) streams, are already studying the Chinese language based on the revised syllabuses. The revised syllabuses have a twin objective: (1) to develop the language proficiency of the students; and (2) to inculcate Asian culture and traditional values. Based on the recommendations of the Committee, we have integrated interesting ways of conveying both these two objectives by including more stories, more poems, more interesting cultural events and so forth, to develop the children's interest in Chinese.

    A second question Dr Ow asked is about the promotion of supplementary reading in Chinese. One of the recommendations of the Review Committee is to set up a Chinese Supplementary Readers' Council and this was set up in 1993 to promote Chinese reading. The Council does this by reviewing and recommending books and distributing lists of supplementary readers to both the primary and secondary schools, junior colleges, and so on. Since 1994, the Council has distributed a total of nine lists of recommended readers, which include a total of 600 titles. 600 titles is quite a long list for supplementary reading. In addition, the Council itself has reviewed and launched a total of five new

Column: 1814

readers. The recommended list is given to the school libraries. They choose which to acquire and the Chinese teachers use them for enriching the students' reading programmes.

    A third question asked by Dr Ow is whether we use multi-media, ie, modern IT technology, in the teaching of Chinese. Yes, we do. In fact, since last year we have been using six new Chinese language multi-media instructional packages for both primary and secondary levels. These have incorporated the recommendations of the Committee based on the revised syllabus, the new word list and so forth.

    Finally, Dr Ow asked how many Chinese language teachers have received upgraded training in the teaching of Chinese. I would like to assure him that for the last three to four years we have been sending Chinese language teachers to attend customised courses in China. In 1995, we sent 30 teachers and in 1996, 40. Before that, for a couple of years, we have already started to send them to specialised courses in China. We have also engaged consultants from China to conduct short training courses locally. The number of teachers who have attended these courses is quite large. In 1995, 147; 1996, 220 (estimated). We also have NIE in-service courses on the teaching of Chinese. Every year we provide these courses to over 100 teachers.

    Mr Sinnakaruppan asked about the teaching of Tamil. On the one hand, he said we should maintain high standards, yet on the other hand, he said that there has been some feedback that the standard which is being taught seems to be a little too high and that there is too much emphasis on grammar. I must admit that I know nothing about the teaching of Tamil, although of course I ask my specialist officers about it. They assure me that the quality of teaching and learning of all the mother tongues is maintained through the setting of equivalent standards in the syllabuses, in the examinations, textbooks and teacher qualifications. The Tamil teachers are required to have the same professional and academic qualifications as all the other language teachers. So the standard is assured. But whether it is

Column: 1815

pitched at too high a standard, I could ask our specialist teachers to take a look at it and see whether we are pitching it at too high a level. But since they told me that they are pitched at equivalent levels across all the mother tongues, perhaps this is a matter of equivalent standards.

    Mr Sinnakaruppan also asked whether the Tamil language course could be upgraded from the diploma level to a degree level course. Yes, there is a shortage of local Tamil teachers. We have noticed that there are fewer and fewer young teachers who want to take up the teaching of Tamil. But to raise the teaching of Tamil from a diploma course to a degree course is only one way of solving the problem. We have been trying to recruit Tamil teachers from India to fill our current shortage. Last year, we recruited 31 teachers from India and all of them have assumed teaching in our schools already.

    As to the nurturing of our local Tamil teachers, it is not just a matter of how many Tamil teachers at present would like to upgrade to a degree course. It is not just a question of the present pool of Tamil teachers. I am sure the aspiration to upgrade is there. But it is also a question of whether a degree course in Tamil language can be sustained over the long run. It is also a question of the entry requirements. How many of the existing Tamil teachers are able to meet the entry requirements for a degree course? The NIE maintains a very high standard that is comparable to NUS for entry to its BA, BSc cum Diploma in Education programme. So we have to look at the profile and requirements before we can commit ourselves to a firm answer. We can certainly look into it. But, as I said, it is not just a question of numbers. It is a question of sustainability. It is also a question of entry standards. Meanwhile, I would like to inform him that the Ministry has supported Tamil teachers who wish to pursue a degree in Tamil language at selected universities in India. They are given study leave, tuition loans, and so on. The number has not been great, but encouraging.

Column: 1816



    On moral education, Dr Ow asked a couple of specific questions. He asked whether the new syllabus has been completely phased in. Yes, I would like to inform him that the revised Civics and Moral Education syllabus has been fully implemented in the primary schools since 1994. For secondary schools, the new syllabus will be completely phased in this year. He asked how we assess the students since there is no examination in Civics and Moral Education. At the primary level, the teachers award grades based on their perception of the behaviour and conduct of the pupils together with inputs given by several teachers. These grades are then entered in the pupils' report cards. So even though Civics and Moral Education is not an examinable subject, grades are given to the students based on the teachers' perception of the students' conduct and behaviour after consultation with several teachers.

    At the secondary level, Civics and Moral Education is assessed through both formal and non-formal modes of assessment. The formal mode is the paper and pen test and this forms about 40% of the weighting. Then there is the non-formal mode which makes up 60% of the weighting. This includes presentations, service oriented activities and projects. He also asked whether we reinforce the teaching of CME through other activities. Yes, CME has always been reinforced by students taking up community service projects, extra-curricular activities, leadership camps, etc.

    He expressed some concern about the discipline of students arising from his emphasis on civics and moral education. I would like to assure him that the situation with school discipline is not a serious one. We have taken several measures this year to help address the problem, even though it has by no means reached a serious proportion. For example, we have formalised the post of a discipline master who now has the status of Head of Department. We have also formalised a school discipline committee which is chaired by the Principal. We are using computers to help us monitor the incidence of discipline problems in schools. We collaborate with parents also. For

Column: 1817

Members' information, school principals as well as teachers hold meet-the-parents sessions in schools and we invite the parents to come and discuss the children's progress. Some schools do it once every six months while others do it once every year. So we maintain constant contact with the parents. If there is any problem with regard to attendance and handing in of assignments, the teachers will call the parents and do home visits.

    With regard to other types of discipline problems where the Police need to be informed and involved, we do that. As far as the more serious discipline problems are concerned, we are closely liaising with the Ministry of Home Affairs, the Police and the Ministry of Community Development. If the case involves the family, we refer it to counselling and social service agencies.
1.45 pm

    My final subject touches on the promotion of a gracious society. This question was raised by Mr Chew Heng Ching who raised the same subject during the debate on the estimates for the Ministry of Information and the Arts. Needless to say, all along our schools have emphasised the importance of courtesy, care and concern to pupils, so that they can develop into gracious young men and women. The school environment itself encourages the development of these traits. The pupils are taught to show respect to the teachers and elders, including visitors to the school. Civics and moral education and the pastoral care programmes are two special programmes that will help to bring up the students into gracious young men and women. And these two programmes are further reinforced through community service projects, and so on.

    The Minister for Information and the Arts also broached the subject of introducing the so-called "Small Kindness Movement" through the Singapore Courtesy Council. At the moment, my Ministry is studying the merits of the proposal and see how we can fit into this. While the schools can play their part in disseminating and teaching graciousness,

Column: 1818

I like to emphasise that our community, ie, the public bodies, the trade unions, the business circles and social groups, must also play a part. They have been participating in the courtesy campaign. I think it just takes a little bit of expansion of the campaign to include the quality of graciousness in the promotion of courtesy throughout Singapore, so that it can become a nation-wide movement.

    I like also to say that the family too must play a role. Parents have to be good role models and they must be prepared to not just teach, but also scold or chide their children whenever they show discourteous or ungracious behaviour. During the debate under the Ministry of Information and the Arts, I think my colleague, Mr Davinder Singh, said that since the parents are working nowadays, they do not have the time. Or if they have the time with their children, they want them to sit down to do their homework, and they have no time to discuss social issues such as graciousness with their children. And he also said that, if I quote him correctly, the responsibility lies squarely on the schools. I disagree with him. The responsibility also lies with the parents. Graciousness such as kindness, politeness, helpfulness, gentleness and civic-mindedness cannot be taught by precepts alone. They must be taught by example, and the parents must also set the example. I must say that I have seen enough instances where our working parents indulge their children so much that sometimes they do not even scold their children when they behave ungraciously in public. I think that is wrong. Parents must also play a part; everybody must play a part.

    Let me respond to Mr Peh first. Sir, MOE has a comprehensive system to help schools to deal with problematic students. At present, teachers in school provide first-level counselling to students with problems. The guidance officers from the Pastoral Care and Career Guidance Branch of our Ministry conducts school-based training on basic counselling skills for teachers. Furthermore, MOE will be conducting in-depth training for teacher counsellors this month. In addition, schools have a disciplinary committee headed by a disciplinary master or mistress to manage students with disciplinary problems. For more problematic students, schools seek the assistance of guidance officers who promptly respond to provide advice and counselling. Where necessary, the schools and the guidance officers work with parents and refer the students to appropriate social service agencies such as the Family Service Centres, the Students' Care Service, the Child Psychiatric Clinic and, of course, the self-help groups. There is also provision for schools to employ qualified part-time counsellors to help students with problems. For problematic students beyond parental control and where close supervision is to be necessary and beneficial, the school generally recommends to place them in residential homes such as the Boys' Town, Pertapis, Marymount Centre where they are closely monitored. These pupils continue their education at mainstream levels.

    Sir, with the existing measures to help students with problems, my Ministry considers that it is not necessary to set up a school only for problematic students where they would be negatively stigmatised and which may also impede their integration back to mainstream schools.

    Sir, Mr Low Thia Khiang made several suggestions, for instance, reduced workload for teachers. We cannot afford to reduce the workload of teachers to enable them to devote their time to help problem students because, as he knows, we do not have adequate manpower. Column: 1821



    Sir, I agree with Mr Low Thia Khiang that if parents cannot look after their children, the schools should do their part. Just like my colleague, I would say there is so much that the schools can do, so much that the self-help groups can do, but not much more. It must be the responsibility of the parents. And I do not think there are teachers who would just let their kids sink or swim. If Mr Low were to know of that particular school, or that particular teacher especially, please let us know.     The exclusive licences were to give ST time to stabilise its operations following its transition into a public company, to let ST to recoup its massive investments in infrastructure, and to allow an orderly evolution to a more competitive environment.     Firstly, TAS has interpreted the scope of ST's exclusive licences narrowly. It has licensed other providers to compete for services which are at the fringe of ST's basic services, or which did not exist when the licence was first issued. As a result of this, new services have proliferated, such as Internet services, value-added services, VSAT, mobile data services, and so on. ST itself has also introduced new services to keep up with the competition. Prices have fallen, giving customers a better deal and service providers a bigger market.

    Secondly, TAS has used other countries as benchmarks to regulate ST's charges for services where ST enjoys an exclusive licence, for example, IDD. The benchmark countries include Hong Kong, Japan, US, UK, Australia, the NIEs and emerging economies. TAS reviews ST's tariffs quarterly, so that they never get too far out of line without competitors. In the last two years, ST has cut IDD rates to 37 countries by up to 47%. Mr Chng Hee Kok mentioned that Singapore Telecom's charges to several countries are not competitive with cities like Sydney, Hong Kong and so on. He is correct, but that was for 1995 rate. I believe that with the recent round of cuts, effective 1st April, Singapore Telecom is competitive with these countries. Therefore, even without any change in regulatory policy, or any increase in the degree of competition in Singapore, over time ST's rates will approach the rates that would prevail in a competitive market.

This statement also appeared in the IPO prospectus. These public telecommunication licensees include mobile cellular phone operators, paging operators and, in future, cable vision operators. The services they can provide will include those where ST has an exclusive licence.
